page.title: Timeline of drafting and ratification of the United States Constitution

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/24.143.19.139|24.143.19.139]] ([[User talk:24.143.19.139|talk]]): No, May 25 is correct ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{US Constitution article series}} The drafting of the [[Constitution of the United States]] began on May 25, 1787, when the [[Constitutional Convention (United States)|Constitutional Convention]] met for the first time with a [[quorum]] at the [[Independence Hall|Pennsylvania State House]] (now Independence Hall) in [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]] to revise the [[Articles of Confederation]], and ended on September 17, 1787, the day the Constitution drafted by the convention's delegates to replace the Articles was adopted and signed. The ratification process for the Constitution began that day, and ended when the final state, [[Rhode Island]], ratified it on May 29, 1790. In addition to key events during the Constitutional Convention and afterward while the Constitution was before the states for their ratification, this timeline includes important events that occurred during the run-up to the convention and during the nation's transition from government under the Articles of Confederation to government under the Constitution, and concludes with the unique ratification vote of [[Vermont Republic|Vermont]], which at the time was a [[sovereign state]] outside the Union. The time span covered is {{age in years and months|Mar 25, 1785|Jan 10, 1791}}, from March 25, 1785 to January 10, 1791.
==1785== ;March 25 • Maryland–Virginia conference convenes :Initially scheduled to assemble in [[Alexandria, Virginia]] on March 21, delegates representing the [[U.S. states|states]] of Maryland and Virginia gather at [[Mount Vernon]], the [[Fairfax County, Virginia|Fairfax County]] home of [[George Washington]], to address navigational [[Riparian water rights|rights]] in the states' common waterways.<ref name=gwmv>{{cite web|title=Mount Vernon Conference|url=https://www.mountvernon.org/library/digitalhistory/digital-encyclopedia/article/mount-vernon-conference/|work=Digital Encyclopedia|publisher=Mount Vernon Ladies' Association, George Washington's Mount Vernon| location=Mount Vernon, Virginia|accessdate=January 9, 2019}}</ref> Attending what later became known as the [[Mount Vernon Conference]] were: [[Daniel of St. Thomas Jenifer]], [[Thomas Stone]], and [[Samuel Chase]], from Maryland; along with [[George Mason]], and [[Alexander Henderson (American politician)|Alexander Henderson]] of Virginia.<ref>{{cite book| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ecgaAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA364&lpg=PA364#v=onepage&q&f=false| page=364| title=Harper's New Monthly Magazine| volume=60| location=New York| publisher=Harper & Brothers| date=1880| editor-first=Henry Mills| editor-last=Alden| version=Digitized May 14, 2008| accessdate=October 5, 2017}}</ref>
;March 28 • Maryland–Virginia conference concludes :Delegates approve a thirteen-point agreement, commonly known as the Mount Vernon Compact, regulating commerce, fishing, and navigation in the waters of the [[Potomac River|Potomac]] and [[Pocomoke River|Pocomoke]] Rivers, and [[Chesapeake Bay]].<ref name=gwmv/> The agreement was subsequently ratified by both the [[Virginia General Assembly|Virginia]] and [[Maryland General Assembly|Maryland]] General Assemblies, becoming the nation's first [[interstate compact]].<ref>{{cite web| url=https://law.lis.virginia.gov/compacts/maryland-virginia-compact-of-1785/| title=Maryland-Virginia Compact of 1785| work=Virginia Law| publisher=Legislative Information System, Commonwealth of Virginia| location=Richmond, Virginia| accessdate=October 5, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=https://msa.maryland.gov/msa/mdstatehouse/html/compact_convention.html| title=The Mt. Vernon Compact & The Annapolis Convention| publisher=Maryland State Archives| location=Annapolis, Maryland| accessdate=January 9, 2019}}</ref>
==1786== ;January 21 • Conference to address certain defects of the federal government called :Virginia General Assembly calls for an interstate convention for the purpose of discussing and developing a consensus about reversing the protectionist trade and commerce barriers existing between the various states.<ref name=Scharf268>{{harvnb|Scharf|1888}}, p. 268</ref>
;September 11 • [[Annapolis Convention (1786)|Annapolis Convention]] convenes : Delegates representing [[Delaware]], [[New Jersey]], [[New York (state)|New York]], [[Pennsylvania]], and Virginia meet at George Mann's Tavern<ref name=SSCaxA>{{harvnb|Wright Jr|MacGregor Jr|1987}}, p. 264</ref> in [[Annapolis, Maryland]] to discuss ways to facilitate commerce between the states and establish standard rules and regulations. Appointed delegates from [[Massachusetts]], [[New Hampshire]], [[North Carolina]], and [[Rhode Island]] either arrived too late to participate or otherwise did not attend.<ref>{{harvnb|Ferling|2003}}, p. 268</ref> Four states: [[Connecticut]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], Maryland and [[South Carolina]], did not appoint delegates.
;September 14 • Annapolis Convention adjourns : The convention report, sent to [[Congress of the Confederation|Congress]] and the legislatures of the various states, contains a request that another convention be held the following May at Philadelphia to discuss amending the Articles of Confederation.<ref name=Scharf268/><ref name=SSCaxA/>
;November 23 • :New Jersey elects delegates to the proposed constitutional convention. [[David Brearley]], [[Jonathan Dayton]], [[William Houston]], [[William Livingston]], and [[William Paterson (judge)|William Paterson]] will attend.<ref name=Bio>{{cite web| url=https://www.archives.gov/founding-docs/founding-fathers| title=Meet the Framers of the Constitution|work=America's Founding Documents|publisher=The U.S. National Archives and Records Administration| location=Washington, D.C.|accessdate=September 7, 2017| date=November 3, 2015}}</ref>
;December 4 • :Virginia elects delegates to the proposed constitutional convention. [[John Blair Jr.]], [[James Madison]], [[George Mason]], [[James McClurg]], [[Edmund Randolph]], [[George Washington]], and [[George Wythe]] will attend.<ref name=Bio/>
;December 30 • :Pennsylvania elects delegates to the proposed constitutional convention. [[George Clymer]], [[Thomas FitzSimons]], [[Benjamin Franklin]], [[Jared Ingersoll]], [[Thomas Mifflin]], [[Gouverneur Morris]], [[Robert Morris (financier)|Robert Morris]], and [[James Wilson (justice)|James Wilson]] will attend.<ref name=Bio/>
==1787== ;January 6 • :North Carolina elects delegates to the proposed constitutional convention. [[William Blount]], [[William Richardson Davie]], [[Alexander Martin]], [[Richard Dobbs Spaight]], and [[Hugh Williamson]] will attend.<ref name=Bio/>
;January 17 • :New Hampshire elects delegates to the proposed Philadelphia Convention. [[Nicholas Gilman]] and [[John Langdon (politician)|John Langdon]] will attend.<ref name=Bio/>
;February 3 • :Delaware elects delegates to the proposed constitutional convention. [[Richard Bassett (Delaware politician)|Richard Bassett]], [[Gunning Bedford, Jr.]], [[Jacob Broom]], and [[John Dickinson (delegate)|John Dickinson]], and [[George Read (U.S. statesman)|George Read]] will attend.<ref name=Bio/>
;February 10 • :Georgia elects delegates to the proposed constitutional convention. [[Abraham Baldwin]], [[William Few]], [[William Houstoun (lawyer)|William Houstoun]], and [[William Pierce (politician)|William Pierce]] will attend.<ref name=Bio/>
;February 21 • Convention to discuss revisions to the Articles of Confederation called :The Congress of the Confederation calls a constitutional convention "for the sole and express purpose of revising the Articles of Confederation and reporting to Congress and the several legislatures such alterations and provisions therein and when agreed to in Congress and confirmed by the States render the Federal Constitution adequate to the exigencies of Government and the preservation of the Union".<ref>{{cite web|title=Resolution of Congress, 21 Feb. 1787|url=http://press-pubs.uchicago.edu/founders/documents/a7s1.html|work= The Founders' Constitution|publisher= University of Chicago Press|accessdate=October 4, 2015}}</ref>
;March 3 • :Massachusetts elects delegates to the upcoming constitutional convention. [[Elbridge Gerry]], [[Nathaniel Gorham]], [[Rufus King]], and [[Caleb Strong]] will attend.<ref name=Bio/>
;March 6 • :New York elects delegates to the upcoming constitutional convention. [[Alexander Hamilton]], [[John Lansing, Jr.]], and [[Robert Yates (politician)|Robert Yates]] will attend.<ref name=Bio/>
;March 8 • :South Carolina elects delegates to the upcoming constitutional convention. [[Pierce Butler]], [[Charles Cotesworth Pinckney]], [[Charles Pinckney (governor)|Charles Pinckney]], and [[John Rutledge]] will attend.<ref name=Bio/>
;April 23 • :Maryland elects delegates to the upcoming constitutional convention. [[Daniel Carroll]], [[Daniel of St. Thomas Jenifer]], [[Luther Martin]], [[James McHenry]], and [[John Francis Mercer|John Mercer]] will attend.<ref name=Bio/>
;May 5 • :A motion to send delegates to the constitutional convention fails in the [[Rhode Island General Assembly]].<ref name=ricitizens>{{cite web|title=Letter from Certain Citizens of Rhode Island to the Federal Convention|url=http://teachingamericanhistory.org/library/document/letter-from-certain-citizens-of-rhode-island-to-the-federal-convention/|publisher=TeachingAmericanHistory.org|accessdate=October 21, 2015|location=Ashland, Ohio}}</ref>
[[File:Independence Hall Clocktower in Philadelphia.jpg|thumb|right|upright=.90|alt=Independence Hall, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania|South facade of Independence Hall (formerly the Pennsylvania Statehouse), Philadelphia, where the Constitution was forged]] ;May 14 • Constitutional Convention scheduled to begin :As only a small number of delegates have arrived in Philadelphia, the convention's opening meeting is postponed for lack of a quorum.<ref name=PMp27>{{harvnb|Maier|2010}}, p. 27</ref>
;May 14 • :Connecticut elects delegates to the constitutional convention. [[Oliver Ellsworth]], [[William Samuel Johnson]] and [[Roger Sherman]] will attend.<ref name=Bio/>
;May 17 • :A letter from "Certain Citizens of Rhode Island" is sent to the convention expressing their support for its work and their regret that not every state will be participating.<ref name=ricitizens/>
;May 25 • Constitutional Convention convenes :As enough delegates have gathered at the Pennsylvania State House to constitute a quorum, the constitutional convention is called to order and delegates begin their work. George Washington is elected [[Chairman|president]] of the convention. [[William Jackson (secretary)|William Jackson]] is selected as the [[secretary]] to the convention. Alexander Hamilton, Charles Pinckney and George Wythe are chosen to prepare rules for the convention.<ref name=CCCs>{{cite journal|last=Vile|first=John R.|title=The Critical Role of Committees at the U.S. Constitutional Convention of 1787|date=April 2006|volume=48|issue=2|pages=147–176|jstor=25434790| doi=10.2307/25434790| journal=The American Journal of Legal History}}</ref>
[[File:George Washington 1795.jpg|thumb|right|upright=.60|alt=George Washington, President of the Constitutional Convention|George Washington, who served as president of the 1787 Constitutional Convention]] [[File:Nathaniel Gorham.jpg|thumb|right|upright=.60|alt=Nathaniel Gorham, Chairman of the Committee of the Whole|Nathaniel Gorham, who served as chairman when delegates met as a Committee of the Whole]] ;May 29 • :[[Virginia Plan]] (also known as the ''Large State Plan'' or the ''Randolph Plan'') for structuring the federal government is presented by Edmund Randolph.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://avalon.law.yale.edu/18th_century/vatexta.asp|title=Variant Texts of the Virginia Plan, Presented by Edmund Randolph to the Federal Convention|publisher=The [[Avalon Project]] at Yale Law School|accessdate=March 31, 2014}}</ref>
;May 29 • :[[Constitutional Convention (United States)#Pinckney's plan|Pinckney Plan]] for structuring the federal government is presented by Charles Pinckney.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://avalon.law.yale.edu/18th_century/pinckney.asp|title=The Plan of Charles Pinckney (South Carolina), Presented to the Federal Convention|publisher=The Avalon Project at Yale Law School|accessdate=March 31, 2014}}</ref>
;May 30 • :Nathaniel Gorham is elected to serve as chairman of the [[Committee of the Whole]].<ref>{{harvnb|Vile|2005}}, p. 324</ref>
;June 15 • :[[New Jersey Plan]] (also known as the ''Small State Plan'' or the ''Paterson Plan'') for structuring the federal government is presented by William Paterson.<ref>{{harvnb|Madison|1787}}, [http://avalon.law.yale.edu/18th_century/debates_615.asp#1 June 15]</ref>
;June 18 • :[[Constitutional Convention (United States)#Hamilton's plan|Hamilton Plan]] (also known as the ''British Plan'') for structuring the federal government is presented by Alexander Hamilton.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://avalon.law.yale.edu/18th_century/hamtexta.asp|title=Variant Texts of the Plan Presented by Alexander Hamilton to the Federal Convention|publisher=The Avalon Project at Yale Law School|accessdate=March 31, 2014}}</ref>
;July 2 • :Committee of Eleven composed of Abraham Baldwin, Gunning Bedford, William Davie, Oliver Ellsworth, Benjamin Franklin, Elbridge Gerry, Luther Martin, George Mason, John Rutledge, William Patterson, and Robert Yates, is selected to work out a compromise on the issue of representation in the two houses of the federal legislature. Committees like this one, composed of one delegate from each state represented, were established on several occasions during the convention in order to secure a breakthrough so that the deliberative process could move forward in a productive fashion.<ref name=committeest>{{cite web|title=Committee Assignments Chart and Commentary|url=http://teachingamericanhistory.org/convention/delegates/committee_table/|publisher=TeachingAmericanHistory.org|accessdate=March 30, 2014|location=Ashland, Ohio}}</ref>
;July 12 • :Delegates from [[Slave states and free states|slave states and those from free states]] adopt the [[Three-Fifths Compromise]] concerning how slaves would be counted when apportioning [[United States House of Representatives|representatives]] and [[direct tax]]es.<ref>{{cite journal| last=Lynd| first=Staughton| title=The Compromise of 1787| journal=Political Science Quarterly| volume=81| issue=2| date=June 1966| pages=225–250| jstor=2147971| doi=10.2307/2147971}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| last=Applestein| first=Donald| title=The three-fifths compromise: Rationalizing the irrational| date=February 12, 2013| url=https://constitutioncenter.org/blog/the-three-fifths-compromise-rationalizing-the-irrational/| work=Constitution Daily| publisher=National Constitution Center| location=Philadelphia, Pennsylvania| accessdate=January 8, 2019}}</ref>
;July 16 • :Committee of Eleven report, proposing proportional representation for seats in the House of Representatives based on population, equal representation for each State in the Senate, and that all money bills would originate in the House, is approved by the convention (5–4–1). This is known as the [[Connecticut Compromise]] (also known as the ''Great Compromise'').<ref>{{harvnb|Madison|1787}}, [http://avalon.law.yale.edu/18th_century/debates_716.asp July 16]</ref>
;July 24 • :[[Committee of Detail]], composed of John Rutledge, Edmund Randolph, Nathaniel Gorham, Oliver Ellsworth, and James Wilson, is selected to write a first draft constitution reflective of the Resolutions passed by the convention up to that point.<ref name=CCCs/>
;August 6 • :Committee of Detail report, proposing a twenty-three article (plus preamble) constitution is presented.<ref>{{harvnb|Madison|1787}}, [http://avalon.law.yale.edu/18th_century/debates_915.asp August 6]</ref>
;August 18 • :Committee of Eleven composed of Abraham Baldwin, George Clymer, John Dickinson, Rufus King, John Langdon, William Livingston, George Mason, James McHenry, Charles C. Pinkney, Roger Sherman, and Hugh Williamson, is selected to address issues related to Federal assumption of state debts. Issues related to the militia are referred to this committee on August 20.<ref name=committeest/>
;August 22 • :Committee of Eleven composed of Abraham Baldwin, George Clymer, John Dickinson, William Johnson, Rufus King, John Langdon, William Livingston, Luther Martin, James Madison, Charles C. Pinkney, and Hugh Williamson, is selected to address issues related to federal tax and duty levying powers and also its power to regulate or prohibit the migration or importation of slaves.<ref name=committeest/>
;August 25 • :Committee of Eleven composed of Pierce Butler, Daniel Carrol, Jonathan Dayton, William Few, Thomas FitzSimons, Nathaniel Gorham, John Langdon, George Mason, George Read, Roger Sherman, and Hugh Williamson, is selected to consider issues related to interstate trade and navigation.<ref name=committeest/>
;August 31 • :Committee of Eleven (Leftover Business) composed of Abraham Baldwin, David Brearly, Pierce Butler, Daniel Carrol, John Dickinson, Nicholas Gilman, Rufus King, James Madison, Gouvernour Morris, Roger Sherman, and Hugh Williamson, is selected to settle "such parts of the Constitution as have been postponed, and such parts of Reports as have not been acted on".<ref name=CCCs/>
[[File:Voting Record of the Constitutional Convention - NARA - 301680.jpg|thumb|right|upright|alt=Voting record of the Constitutional Convention, September 15, 1787|The convention voting record, which reflects the mutual concessions and compromises that produced the Constitution; this page records the final vote taken September 15, 1787]] ;September 1–8 • :Committee of Eleven (Leftover Business) addresses several outstanding issues—including the method of choosing a president, the length of a presidential term of office, the president's treaty making power, and the impeachment of the president—and makes a series of reports.<ref name=committeest/>
;September 8 • :Committee of Style and Arrangement, composed of Alexander Hamilton, William Johnson, Rufus King, James Madison, and Gouverneur Morris, is selected to distill a final draft constitution from the twenty-three approved articles.<ref name=CCCs/>
;September 12 • :Committee of Style and Arrangement presents the completed final draft of the Constitution to the convention for its consideration. The twenty-three articles have been reorganized into a cohesive document containing seven articles, a [[Preamble to the United States Constitution|preamble]] and a [[eschatocol|closing endorsement]], of which Gouverneur Morris was the primary author.<ref name=Bio/> The committee also presented a proposed letter to accompany the constitution when delivered to Congress.<ref>{{harvnb|Madison|1787}}, [http://avalon.law.yale.edu/18th_century/debates_915.asp September 12]</ref>
;September 13–14 • :The official copy of the draft Constitution is [[Western calligraphy|engrossed]] by [[Jacob Shallus]].<ref>{{harvnb|Vile|2005}}, p. 705</ref>
;September 15 • :The draft Constitution receives the unanimous approval of the state delegations.<ref>{{harvnb|Madison|1787}}, [http://avalon.law.yale.edu/18th_century/debates_915.asp September 15]</ref>
[[File:Scene at the Signing of the Constitution of the United States.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.05|alt=Scene at the Signing of the United States Constitution|[[Howard Chandler Christy]]'s 1940 ''[[Scene at the Signing of the Constitution of the United States]]'']] ;September 17 • Constitution signed and convention adjourns :The approved Constitution is signed by thirty-nine delegates from twelve states (all but Rhode Island). One delegate, John Dickinson, who was ill and not present, had George Read sign his name by proxy. Three delegates present declined to sign the document: Edmund Randolph, George Mason, and Elbridge Gerry. George Washington, as president of the convention, signed first. The other delegates then signed, grouped by state in strict congressional voting order. Washington, however, signed near the right [[Margin (typography)|margin]], and so when the delegates ran out of space beneath his signature, they began a second column of signatures to the left. Jackson, the convention secretary, also signed as a witness. The convention then adjourned ''[[adjournment sine die|sine die]]''.<ref name=SSCaxA/>
;September 18 • Proposed Constitution published :The Pennsylvania Packet prints the first [[Broadside (printing)|public copies]] of the proposed Constitution in Philadelphia.<ref name=PMp27/>
;September 20 • :Proposed Constitution is received by Congress.<ref>{{harvnb|Maier|2010}}, p. 52</ref>
;September 27 • :First [[Anti-Federalist]] letter by "Cato" is published.<ref>{{cite web|title=Cato I|url=http://teachingamericanhistory.org/library/document/cato-i/|publisher=TeachingAmericanHistory.org|accessdate=March 30, 2014|location=Ashland, Ohio}}</ref>
;September 28 • :Congress of the Confederation votes to transmit the proposed Constitution to the thirteen states for ratification by the people in state conventions, as prescribed In its [[Article Seven of the United States Constitution|Article Seven]].<ref>{{harvnb|Elliot|1836a}}, p. [http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/ampage?collId=lled&fileName=001/lled001.db&recNum=334&itemLink=r%3Fammem%2Fhlaw%3A%40field%28DOCID%2B%40lit%28ed0019%29%29%3A%230010011&linkText=1 319]</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Maier|2010}}, pp. 54–58</ref>
;October 5 • :First Anti-Federalist letter by "[[Letters of Centinel|Centinel]]" is published.<ref>{{cite web|title=Centinel I|url=http://teachingamericanhistory.org/library/document/centinel-i/|publisher=TeachingAmericanHistory.org|accessdate=March 30, 2014|location=Ashland, Ohio}}</ref>
;October 8 • :First Anti-Federalist letter by "[[Federal Farmer]]" is published.<ref>{{cite web|title=Federal Farmer I|url=http://teachingamericanhistory.org/library/document/federal-farmer-i/|publisher=TeachingAmericanHistory.org|accessdate=March 30, 2014|location=Ashland, Ohio}}</ref>
;October 18 • :First Anti-Federalist letter by "[[Robert Yates (politician)|Brutus]]" is published.<ref>{{cite web|title=Brutus I|url=http://teachingamericanhistory.org/library/document/brutus-i/|publisher=TeachingAmericanHistory.org|accessdate=March 30, 2014|location=Ashland, Ohio}}</ref>
[[File:An Advertisement of The Federalist - Project Gutenberg eText 16960.jpg|thumb|right|upright=.70|alt=A 1787 advertisement for The Federalist|An advertisement for ''The Federalist'', 1787, using the pseudonym "Philo-Publius"]] ;October 27 • :First of ''[[The Federalist Papers]]'' by "Publius", [[Federalist No. 1]], is published in ''[[The Independent Journal]]''.<ref>{{harvnb|Millican|1990}}, p. 58</ref> The planned series of essays would, the authors hoped, "give a satisfactory answer to all the ''[Anti-Federalist]'' objections which shall have made their appearance, that may seem to have any claim to your attention."<ref>{{harvnb|Gunn|1994}}, p. 540</ref>
;November 20 • :Ratifying convention begins in Pennsylvania.<ref>{{harvnb|Maier|2010}}, p. 100</ref>
;December 3 • :Ratifying convention begins in Delaware.<ref>{{harvnb|Maier|2010}}, p. 122</ref>
;December 7 • Ratification [[File:Seal of Delaware.svg|30px]] :Delaware becomes the first state to ratify the Constitution (30–0).<ref name=Ratification>{{harvnb|Kilpatrick|1961}}, p. 24</ref><ref name=JRVlist>{{harvnb|Vile|2005}}, p. 658</ref>
;December 11 • :Ratifying convention begins in New Jersey.<ref name=NJDOS>{{cite web|title=1787 Convention Minutes|url=https://www.nj.gov/state/archives/doc1787conventionminutes.html|publisher=[[Government of New Jersey|New Jersey Department of State]]|accessdate=January 9, 2019}}</ref>
;December 12 • Ratification [[File:Seal of Pennsylvania.svg|30px]] :Pennsylvania becomes the second state to ratify the Constitution (46–23).<ref name=Ratification/><ref name=JRVlist/>
;December 18 • Ratification [[File:Seal of New Jersey.svg|30px]] :New Jersey becomes the third state to ratify the Constitution (38–0).<ref name=Ratification/><ref name=JRVlist/><ref name=NJDOS/>
;December 18 • :Pennsylvania convention Anti-Federalist minority publishes their "Dissent".<ref>{{cite web|title=The Dissent of the Minority of the Convention of Pennsylvania|url=http://teachingamericanhistory.org/library/document/the-dissent-of-the-minority-of-the-convention-of-pennsylvania/|publisher=TeachingAmericanHistory.org|accessdate=March 30, 2014|location=Ashland, Ohio}}</ref>
;December 25 • :Ratifying convention begins in Georgia.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Georgia Ratifying Convention Meets|url=http://teachingamericanhistory.org/library/document/the-georgia-ratifying-convention-meets/|accessdate=October 21, 2015|publisher=TeachingAmericanHistory.org|location=Ashland, Ohio}}</ref>
==1788== ;January 2 • Ratification [[File:Seal of Georgia.svg|30px]] :Georgia becomes the fourth state to ratify the Constitution (26–0).<ref name=Ratification/><ref name=JRVlist/>
;January 3 • :Ratifying convention begins in Connecticut.<ref>{{harvnb|Maier|2010}}, p. 137</ref>
;January 9 • Ratification [[File:Seal of Connecticut.svg|26px]] :Connecticut becomes the fifth state to ratify the Constitution (128–40).<ref name=Ratification/><ref name=JRVlist/>
;January 9 • :Ratifying convention begins in Massachusetts.<ref>{{harvnb|Maier|2010}}, p. 155</ref>
;February 6 • Ratification [[File:Seal of Massachusetts.svg|30px]] :Massachusetts becomes the sixth state to ratify the Constitution (187–168).<ref name=Ratification/><ref name=JRVlist/> In addition to ratifying the constitution, Massachusetts requests that nineteen [[Massachusetts Compromise|alterations]] be made to it.<ref>{{harvnb|Elliot|1836a}}, p. [http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/ampage?collId=lled&fileName=001/lled001.db&recNum=337&itemLink=r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(ed001179)):%230010350&linkText=1 322]</ref>
;February 13–22 • :Ratifying convention (first session) held in New Hampshire.<ref name=pm125>{{harvnb|Maier|2010}}, p. 125</ref>
;March 1 • :Flouting the letter and spirit of Article Seven of the proposed Constitution , the [[Rhode Island General Assembly]] calls for a statewide [[referendum]] rather than a state convention.<ref name=RIreferendum>{{cite web| title=The Rhode Island State Referendum on the Constitution| url=https://csac.history.wisc.edu/states-and-ratification/rhode-island/referendum/| website=csac.history.wisc.edu| publisher=Center for the Study of the American Constitution, University of Wisconsin–Madison| accessdate=January 8, 2019}}</ref><ref name=ChaputDeSimone>{{cite web| last1=Chaput| first1=Erik| last2=DeSimone| first2=Russell J.| title=Providence's Merchants Influence the State to Ratify the U.S. Constitution in 1790| url=http://smallstatebighistory.com/providences-merchants-influence-state-ratify-u-s-constitution-1790/| date=February 11, 2015| website=smallstatebighistory.com| accessdate=January 8, 2019}}</ref>
;March 24 • :Voters in Rhode Island overwhelmingly reject the Constitution (2,708–237).<ref name=RIreferendum/><ref name=ChaputDeSimone/>
;April 10 • :[[Albany Antifederal Committee]] publishes a circular forcefully objecting to the proposed constitution, calling the frame of government "more arbitrary and despotic than that of Great Britain."<ref>{{harvnb|Maier|2010}}, p. 333</ref>
;April 21 • :Ratifying convention begins in Maryland.<ref name=pm125/>
;April 28 • Ratification [[File:Seal of Maryland (reverse).svg|30px]] :Maryland becomes the seventh state to ratify the Constitution (63–11).<ref name=Ratification/><ref name=JRVlist/>
;May 12 • :Ratifying convention begins in South Carolina.<ref name=ElliotSC>{{harvnb|Elliot|1836a}}, p. [http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/ampage?collId=lled&fileName=001/lled001.db&recNum=340&itemLink=r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(ed001179)):%230010350&linkText=1 325]</ref>
;May 23 • Ratification [[File:Seal of South Carolina.svg|30px]] :South Carolina becomes the eighth state to ratify the Constitution (149–73).<ref name=Ratification/><ref name=JRVlist/> In addition to ratifying the constitution, South Carolina requests that two alterations be made to it.<ref name=ElliotSC/>
;June 2 • :[[Virginia Ratifying Convention|Ratifying convention]] begins in Virginia.<ref name=pm125/>
;June 17 • :Ratifying convention begins in New York.<ref>{{harvnb|Maier|2010}}, p. 348</ref>
;June 18 • :Ratifying convention (second session) begins in New Hampshire.<ref>{{harvnb|Maier|2010}}, p. 315</ref>
;June 21 • Ratification [[File:Seal of New Hampshire.svg|30px]] :New Hampshire becomes the ninth state to ratify the Constitution (57–47).<ref name=Ratification/><ref name=JRVlist/> In addition to ratifying the constitution, New Hampshire requests that twelve alterations be made to it.<ref>{{harvnb|Elliot|1836a}}, p. [http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/ampage?collId=lled&fileName=001/lled001.db&recNum=341&itemLink=r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(ed001179)):%230010350&linkText=1 326]</ref>
[[File:Dates US Constitution ratified by the 13 States.png|thumb|right|Dates the 13 states ratified the Constitution]] ;June 21 • :Having been ratified by nine of the thirteen states, the Constitution is officially established.<ref>{{harvnb|Maier|2010}}, p. 361</ref>
;June 25 • Ratification [[File:Seal of Virginia.svg|30px]] :Virginia becomes the tenth state to ratify the Constitution (89–79).<ref name=Ratification/><ref name=JRVlist/> In addition to ratifying the constitution, Virginia requests that 20 alterations be made to it.<ref>{{harvnb|Elliot|1836c}}, pp. [http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/ampage?collId=lled&fileName=003/lled003.db&recNum=670&itemLink=r%3Fammem%2Fhlaw%3A%40field%28DOCID%2B%40lit%28ed0032%29%29%3A%230030003&linkText=1 659–661]</ref>
;July 2 • :Congress President [[Cyrus Griffin]] informs Congress that New Hampshire has ratified the Constitution and notes that this is the ninth ratification transmitted to them. A committee is formed to examine all ratifications received thus far and to develop a plan for putting the new Constitution into operation.<ref name=ElliotCong>{{harvnb|Elliot|1836a}}, pp. [http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/ampage?collId=lled&fileName=001/lled001.db&recNum=348&itemLink=r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(ed001177)):%230010349&linkText=1 332–333]</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Maier|2010}}, pp. 376–377</ref>
;July 21 – August 2 • :First [[Hillsborough Convention|ratifying convention]] held in Hillsborough, North Carolina. With the hope of effecting the incorporation of a bill of rights into the frame of government, delegates vote (184–84) neither to ratify nor to reject the Constitution.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hillsborough Convention of 1788|url=http://northcarolinahistory.org/encyclopedia/hillsborough-convention-of-1788/|author=North Carolina History Project|publisher=[[John Locke Foundation]]|location=Raleigh, North Carolina|accessdate=October 12, 2015}}</ref>
;July 26 • Ratification [[File:Seal of New York.svg|30px]] :New York becomes the eleventh state to ratify the Constitution (30–27).<ref name=Ratification/><ref name=JRVlist/> In addition to ratifying the constitution, New York issues a [[New York Circular Letter|circular letter]] requesting that 33 alterations be made to it, and also that the new United States Congress take positive action on all amendments demanded by other state ratifying conventions.<ref>{{harvnb|Elliot|1836a}}, pp. [http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/ampage?collId=lled&fileName=001/lled001.db&recNum=344&itemLink=r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(ed001179)):%230010350&linkText=1 329–319]</ref>
;September 13 • :Congress of the Confederation certifies that the new constitution has been duly ratified and sets date for first meeting of the [[Federal government of the United States|new federal government]] and the [[United States presidential election|presidential election]].<ref name=ElliotCong/><ref>{{harvnb|Maier|2010}}, p. 429</ref>
;December 15, 1788 – January 10, 1789 • Presidential election held :First quadrennial [[1788–89 United States presidential election|presidential election]] under the new Constitution is held.<ref name=gwmv2>{{cite web|title=Presidential Election of 1789|url=https://www.mountvernon.org/library/digitalhistory/digital-encyclopedia/article/presidential-election-of-1789/|work=Digital Encyclopedia|publisher=Mount Vernon Ladies' Association, George Washington's Mount Vernon| location=Mount Vernon, Virginia| accessdate=January 9, 2019}}</ref>
==1789== ;February 4 • Electoral College convenes :[[Electoral College (United States)|Presidential electors]] meet to cast their votes in their respective states. George Washington is unanimously elected to be the nation's first [[President of the United States|president]] and [[John Adams]] is elected its first [[Vice President of the United States|vice president]], receiving 34 of 69 votes cast. Only ten of the thirteen states cast electoral votes in this election. North Carolina and Rhode Island were ineligible to participate as they had not yet ratified the Constitution. The New York legislature failed to appoint its allotted electors in time, so there were no voting electors from New York.<ref name=gwmv2/><ref>{{harvnb|Maier|2010}}, p. 438</ref>
[[File:New York City Hall 1789b.jpg|thumb|right|alt=Federal Hall, New York, New York|Federal Hall, [[New York City]], first [[seat of government]] of the United States under the Constitution]] ;March 4 • United States Congress convenes :The federal government begins operations under the new form of government as members of the [[1st United States Congress]] are seated at [[Federal Hall]] in New York City. The Senate of eleven states would include 20 Federalists and two Anti-federalists (both from Virginia). The House would seat 48 Federalists and 11 Anti-federalists (from four states: Massachusetts, New York, South Carolina, and Virginia).<ref>{{harvnb|Maier|2010}}, p. 433</ref> However, the initial meeting of each chamber must be adjourned due to lack of a [[quorum]].<ref>{{cite web|title=March 4: A forgotten huge day in American history|url=https://constitutioncenter.org/blog/march-4-a-forgotten-huge-day-in-american-politics/|publisher=[[National Constitution Center]]|accessdate=October 21, 2015|location=Philadelphia|date=March 4, 2013}}</ref>
;April 1 • House of Representatives achieves its first quorum :With a quorum being present representatives begin their work. [[Frederick Muhlenberg]] of Pennsylvania is elected [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives|Speaker of the House]].<ref>{{cite web| url=https://history.house.gov/HistoricalHighlight/Detail/36875?ret=True| title=The First Quorum of the House of Representatives: April 01, 1789| publisher=Office of the Historian and the Clerk of the House's Office of Art and Archives, U.S. House of Representatives| accessdate=January 9, 2019}}</ref>
;April 6 • Senate achieves its first quorum :With a quorum being present senators begin their work. [[John Langdon (politician)|John Langdon]] of New Hampshire is elected [[President pro tempore of the United States Senate|President pro tempore of the Senate]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Langdon, John, (1741{{snd}}1819)|url=http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=L000067| work=[[Biographical Directory of the United States Congress]]| publisher=United States Congress| accessdate=January 9, 2019}}</ref>
;April 6 • Electoral votes counted :The House and Senate, meeting in joint session, certify that George Washington has been elected President of the United States and John Adams elected as Vice President.<ref name=gwmv2/><ref>{{cite web | title=Senate Journal. 1st Congress, 1st session| date=April 6, 1789| page=7| url=http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/ampage?collId=llsj&fileName=001/llsj001.db&recNum=4}}</ref>
;April 21 • John Adams assumes vice presidential duties :John Adams is sworn in as Vice President of the United States in the Senate chamber at Federal Hall in New York City.<ref>{{harvnb|Smith|1962}}, pp.744</ref>
[[File:Washington's Inauguration.jpg|thumb|right|alt=George Washington, inaugurated as President, April 30, 1789|George Washington's inauguration as the first President of the United States, April 30, 1789]] ;April 30 • George Washington assumes presidential duties :George Washington [[First inauguration of George Washington|inaugurated]] as President of the United States at Federal Hall in New York City. Washington placed his hand upon a [[George Washington Inaugural Bible|Bible]] belonging to the [[Grand Lodge of New York|St. John's Lodge No. 1, A.Y.M.]]<ref>{{cite web|title=George Washington Inaugural Bible|url=http://www.stjohns1.org/portal/gwib|publisher=St. John's Lodge No. 1, AYM|accessdate=October 4, 2015}}</ref> as [[Chancellor of New York]] [[Robert R. Livingston (chancellor)|Robert Livingston]] administered the presidential [[Oath of office of the President of the United States|oath of office]].<ref name=gwmv2/><ref>{{cite web |title=George Washington's Inaugural Address |url=https://www.archives.gov/legislative/features/gw-inauguration/ |publisher=The National Archives |accessdate=October 4, 2015}}</ref>
;September 25 • Constitutional amendments proposed by Congress :Twelve articles of amendment to the Constitution are approved by the Senate, having been passed by the House on the preceding day, both without recorded vote, and sent to the states for ratification.<ref>{{harvnb|Labunski|2006}}, p.240</ref> Articles Three through Twelve were ratified as additions to the Constitution December 15, 1791, and are collectively known as the [[United States Bill of Rights|Bill of Rights]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Constitution of the United States—A History|work=America's Founding Documents|url=https://www.archives.gov/founding-docs/more-perfect-union|publisher=[[National Archives and Records Administration]]|accessdate=October 4, 2015|location=Washington D.C.}}</ref> Article Two became part of the Constitution May 7, 1992 as the [[Twenty-seventh Amendment to the United States Constitution|Twenty-seventh Amendment]].<ref>{{cite web| title=The Constitution of the United States of America: Analysis and Interpretation| editor1-last=Killian| editor1-first=Johnny H.| editor2-last=Costello| editor2-first=George A.| editor3-last=Thomas| editor3-first=Kenneth R.| url=https://www.govinfo.gov/content/pkg/GPO-CONAN-2002/pdf/GPO-CONAN-2002.pdf| date=2004|publisher=U.S. Government Printing Office| location=Washington, D.C.| page=44 n.19| work=U.S. Senate Document No. 108–17| others=Contributors: David M. Ackerman, Henry Cohen, Robert Meltz| accessdate=January 8, 2019}}</ref> [[Congressional Apportionment Amendment|Article One]] is technically still pending before the states.<ref name=Ratification/>
;November 16 • :Second ratifying convention begins in [[Fayetteville Convention|Fayetteville, North Carolina]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Minutes of the North Carolina Constitutional Convention at Fayetteville|url=https://docsouth.unc.edu/csr/index.html/document/csr22-0002|website=Documenting the American South|publisher=UNC University Library|accessdate=October 21, 2015}}</ref>
;November 21 • Ratification [[File:Seal of North Carolina.svg|30px]] :North Carolina becomes the twelfth state to ratify the Constitution (194–77).<ref name=Ratification/><ref name=JRVlist/> In addition to ratifying the constitution, North Carolina requests that twenty-six alterations be made to it.<ref>{{harvnb|Elliot|1836d}}, pp. [http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/ampage?collId=lled&fileName=004/lled004.db&recNum=255&itemLink=r%3Fammem%2Fhlaw%3A%40field%28DOCID%2B%40lit%28ed0042%29%29%230040003&linkText=1 244–247]</ref>
==1790== ;February 2 • Supreme Court of the United States convenes :The [[Supreme Court of the United States]] holds its inaugural session with a quorum present at the [[Royal Exchange, New York|Royal Exchange Building]] on Broad Street in New York City, with [[Chief Justice of the United States|Chief Justice]] [[John Jay]] presiding.<ref>{{Cite web| title=The Court as an Institution| url=https://www.supremecourt.gov/about/institution.aspx| publisher=Public Information Office, Supreme Court of the United States| location=Washington, D.C.| accessdate=February 28, 2018}}</ref> As set by the [[Judiciary Act of 1789]], the Supreme Court would initially consist of a chief justice and five [[Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States|associate justices]].<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.fjc.gov/history/legislation/landmark-legislation-judiciary-act-1789| title=Landmark Legislation: Judiciary Act of 1789| publisher=Federal Judicial Center| location=Washington, D.C.| accessdate=February 28, 2018}}</ref>
;March 1–6 • :[[Ratification of the United States Constitution by Rhode Island|Ratifying convention]] (first session) held in Rhode Island.<ref name=ChaputDeSimone/><ref name=Nesi2010WPRI>{{cite news|last1=Nesi|first1=Ted|title=Rhode Islanders were not feelin’ the Constitution|url=http://wpri.com/blog/2010/12/23/rhode-islanders-were-not-feelin-the-constitution/|accessdate=November 24, 2016|work=[[WPRI-TV]]|date=December 23, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161124025016/http://wpri.com/blog/2010/12/23/rhode-islanders-were-not-feelin-the-constitution/|archive-date=November 24, 2016|url-status=dead|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
;May 24 • :Ratifying convention (second session) begins in Rhode Island.<ref name=Nesi2010WPRI/>
;May 29 • Ratification [[File:Seal of Rhode Island.svg|30px]] :Rhode Island becomes the thirteenth and final state to ratify the Constitution (34–32).<ref name=Ratification/><ref name=JRVlist/> In addition to ratifying the constitution, Rhode Island requests that twenty-one alterations be made to it.<ref>{{harvnb|Elliot|1836a}}, pp. [http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/ampage?collId=lled&fileName=001/lled001.db&recNum=351&itemLink=r%3Fammem%2Fhlaw%3A%40field%28DOCID%2B%40lit%28ed001179%29%29%3A%230010350&linkText=1 336–337]</ref>
==1791== ;January 6 • :Convention to consider joining the United States begins in Vermont.<ref name=vermont>{{cite journal|last=Forbes|first=C.S.|title=Vermont's Admission to the Union|journal=The Vermonter: A State Magazine|date=March 1902|volume=VII|issue=8|page=102|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nFMSAAAAYAAJ&pg=RA2-PA101&dq#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=March 29, 2014}}</ref>
;January 10 • Ratification and application [[File:Seal of Vermont (B&W).svg|30px]] :Vermont votes to ratify the Constitution and to apply for admission to the Union (105–2).<ref name=vermont/>
